17656.text: §¶The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz which he beheld concerning Judea and Jerusalem during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah:

17657.text: ¶Hear, O heavens! Give heed, O earth!/_Jehovah has spoken:/I have reared sons, brought them up,/_but they have revolted against me.

17658.text: /The ox knows its owner,/_the ass its master’s stall,/but Israel does not know;/_my people are insensible.

17659.text: /Alas, a nation astray,/_a people weighed down by sin,/the offspring of wrongdoers,/_perverse children:/they have forsaken Jehovah,/_they have spurned the Holy One of Israel,/they have lapsed into apostasy.

17660.text: ¶Why be smitten further/_by adding to your waywardness?/The whole head is sick,/_the whole heart diseased.

17661.text: /From the soles of the feet even to the head/_there is nothing sound,/only wounds and bruises and festering sores;/_they have not been pressed out or bound up,/_nor soothed with ointment.

17662.text: ¶Your land is ruined,/_your cities burned with fire;/your native soil is devoured by aliens in your presence,/_laid waste at its takeover by foreigners.

17663.text: /The Daughter of Zion is left/_like a shelter in a vineyard,/a hut in a melon field,/_a city under siege.

17664.text: /Had not Jehovah of Hosts left us a few survivors,/_we should have been as Sodom,/or become like Gomorrah.

17665.text: ¶Hear the word of Jehovah,/_O leaders of Sodom;/give heed to the law of our God,/_you people of Gomorrah!

17666.text: /For what purpose are your abundant/_sacrifices to me? says Jehovah./I have had my fill of offerings of rams/_and fat of fatted beasts;/the blood of bulls and sheep and he‐goats/_I do not want.

17667.text: /When you come to see me,/_who requires you to trample my courts so?

17668.text: ¶Bring no more worthless offerings;/_they are as a loathsome incense to me./As for convening meetings at the New Month/_and on the Sabbath,/wickedness with the solemn gathering/_I cannot approve.

17669.text: /Your monthly and regular meetings/_my soul detests./They have become a burden on me;/_I am weary of putting up with them.

17670.text: /When you spread forth your hands,/_I will conceal my eyes from you;/though you pray at length, I will not hear—/_your hands are filled with blood.

17671.text: ¶Wash yourselves clean:/_remove your wicked deeds/from before my eyes;/_cease to do evil.

17672.text: /Learn to do good: demand justice,/_stand up for the oppressed;/plead the cause of the fatherless,/_appeal on behalf of the widow.

17673.text: ¶Come now, let us put it to the test,/_says Jehovah:/though your sins are as scarlet,/_they can be made white as snow;/though they have reddened as crimson,/_they may become white as wool.

17674.text: /If you are willing and obey,/_you shall eat the good of the land.

17675.text: /But if you are unwilling and disobey,/_you shall be eaten by the sword./By his mouth Jehovah has spoken it.

17676.text: ¶How the faithful city/_has become a harlot!/She was filled with justice;/_righteousness made its abode in her,/_but now murderers.

17677.text: /Your silver has become dross,/_your wine diluted with water.

17678.text: /Your rulers are renegades,/_accomplices of robbers:/with one accord they love bribes/_and run after rewards;/they do not dispense justice to the fatherless,/_nor does the widow’s case come before them.

17679.text: ¶Therefore the Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_the Valiant One of Israel, declares,/Woe to them! I will relieve me/_of my adversaries,/_avenge me of my enemies.

17680.text: ¶I will restore my hand over you/_and smelt away your dross as in a crucible,/_and remove all your alloy.

17681.text: /I will restore your judges as at the first,/_and your counsellors as in the beginning./After this you shall be called/_the City of Righteousness, a faithful city.

17682.text: ¶For Zion shall be ransomed by justice,/_those of her who repent by righteousness.

17683.text: /But criminals and sinners/_shall be altogether shattered/when those who forsake Jehovah are annihilated.

17684.text: ¶And you will be ashamed of the oaks you cherished/_and blush for the parks you were fond of;

17685.text: /you shall become like an oak whose leaves wither,/_and as a garden that has no water.

17686.text: /The mighty shall be as refuse,/_and their works a spark;/both shall burn up alike,/_and there shall be none to extinguish.

17687.text: ¶A prophecy concerning Judea and Jerusalem which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw in vision:

17688.text: ¶In the latter days/_the mountain of Jehovah’s house/shall become established/_as the head of the mountains;/it shall be preeminent among the hills,/_and all nations will flow to it.

17689.text: /Many peoples shall go, saying,/_Come, let us go up/to the mountain of Jehovah,/_to the house of the God of Jacob,/that he may instruct us in his ways,/_that we may follow in his paths./For out of Zion shall go forth the law,/_and from Jerusalem the word of Jehovah.

17690.text: /He will judge between the nations/_and arbitrate for many peoples./They will beat their swords into plowshares,/_their spears into pruning hooks:/nation will not lift the sword against nation,/_nor will they learn warfare any more.

17691.text: ¶O house of Jacob, come,/_let us follow the light of Jehovah.

17692.text: ¶For you, O Jehovah, have forsaken your people,/_the house of Jacob, because,/like the Philistines,/_they provide themselves with/_mystics from the East/and are content with the infantile heathen.

17693.text: /Their land is full of silver and gold/_and there is no end to their wealth;/their land is full of horses/_and there is no end to their chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is full of idols:/_they adore the works of their hands,/_things their own fingers have made.

17695.text: ¶Mankind is brought low/_when men thus debase themselves./Forbear them not!

17696.text: ¶Go into the rocks; hide in the dust/_from the awesome presence of Jehovah/_and from the brightness of his glory.

17697.text: /The haughty eyes of men shall be lowered/_and man’s pride abased;/Jehovah alone shall be exalted in that day.

17698.text: ¶Jehovah of Hosts has a day in store/_for all the proud and arrogant/and for all who are exalted,/_that they may be brought low.

17699.text: ¶It shall come against all the lofty/_cedars of Lebanon that lift themselves up high,/_and against all the oaks of Bashan,

17700.text: /against all high mountains and elevated hills,

17701.text: against every tall tower and reinforced wall,

17702.text: /against [all vessels at sea,]/_both merchant ships and pleasure craft.

17703.text: /The haughtiness of men shall be abased,/_and man’s pride brought low;/Jehovah alone shall be exalted in that day.

17704.text: ¶He will utterly supplant the false gods.

17705.text: ¶Men will go into caves in the rocks/_and holes in the ground,/from the awesome presence of Jehovah/_and from the brightness of his glory,/_when he arises and strikes terror on earth.

17706.text: /In that day men will throw away/_to the moles and to the bats/their idols of silver and gods of gold/_which they have made for themselves/_to adore.

17707.text: ¶Men will go into crevices in the rocks/_and fissures in the cliffs,/from the awesome presence of Jehovah/_and from the brightness of his glory,/when he arises and strikes terror on earth.

17708.text: ¶Desist from the things of man,/_in whose nostrils is but breath!/For of what consideration is he?

17709.text: ¶Even now, the Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_deprives Judea and Jerusalem/of both staff and crutch—/_all food supply and water supply,

17710.text: /the valiant man and soldier,/_the magistrate and prophet, the augur and elder,

17711.text: /the officer and dignitary,/_advisers, skilled craftsmen, and orators.

17712.text: /I, Jehovah, will make adolescents their rulers;/_delinquents will lord it over them.

17713.text: /People will oppress one another,/_every man his neighbor./The young will be insolent to the elderly,/_the vile to the honorable.

17714.text: ¶Then will a man apprehend a kinsman/_of his father’s house, and say,/You have a tunic: be our leader/_and take charge of this ruination!

17715.text: /But he will raise his hand in that day/_and swear, I am no physician./There is neither food nor clothing in my house;/_you cannot make me a leader of the people.

17716.text: ¶Jerusalem will falter and Judea fall/_because their tongue and their actions/are contrary to Jehovah,/_an affront to his glory before his very eyes.

17717.text: /The look on their faces betrays them:/_they flaunt their sin like Sodom;/_they cannot hide it./Woe to their souls;/_they have brought disaster upon themselves!

17718.text: ¶Tell the righteous it shall be well with them;/_they shall eat the fruits of their own labors.

17719.text: /But woe to the wicked/_when calamity overtakes them:/they shall be paid back/_for the deeds they have done!

17720.text: ¶As for my people, babes subject them;/_women wield authority over them./O my people, your leaders mislead you,/_abolishing your traditional ways.

17721.text: /Jehovah will take a stand and contend with them;/_he has arisen to judge the nations.

17722.text: /He will bring to trial the elders of his people/_and their rulers, and say to them,/It is you who have devoured the vineyard;/_you fill your houses by depriving the needy.

17723.text: /What do you mean by oppressing my people,/_humbling the faces of the poor?/says Jehovah of Hosts.

17724.text: ¶Jehovah says, moreover,/_Because the women of Zion are haughty/and put on airs, painting their eyes,/_ever flirting when they walk/_and clacking with their feet,

17725.text: /my Lord will afflict the scalps/_of the women of Zion with baldness;/Jehovah will expose their private parts.

17726.text: ¶In that day my Lord will strip away their finery—the anklets, head ornaments and crescents,

17728.text: tiaras, bracelets and ribbons, zodiac signs and charm amulets,

17730.text: the elegant dress, the shawl, the kerchief and the purse,

17731.text: hosiery, sheer linen, millinery, and cloaks.

17732.text: ¶And instead of perfume there shall be a stench,/_instead of the girdle, a piece of twine,/instead of the coiffure, baldness,/_instead of the festive dress, a loincloth of burlap;/for in place of beauty/_there shall be ignominy.

17733.text: /Your men shall be felled by the sword,/_your might overthrown in war.

17734.text: /Her gateways shall lie bereaved and forlorn;/_she shall sit on the ground destitute.

17735.text: ¶Seven women will take hold of one man/_in that day, and say,/We will eat our own food,/_wear our own clothes,/only let us be called by your name—/_take away our reproach!

17736.text: ¶In that day the plant of Jehovah shall be beautiful and glorious, and the earth’s fruit the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.

17737.text: Then shall they who are left in Zion and they who remain in Jerusalem be called holy—all who were inscribed to be among the living at Jerusalem.

17738.text: This shall be when my Lord has washed away the excrement of the women of Zion and cleansed Jerusalem of its bloodshed, in the spirit of justice, by a burning wind.

17739.text: Over the whole site of Mount Zion, and over its solemn assembly, Jehovah will form a cloud by day and a mist glowing with fire by night: above all that is glorious shall be a canopy.

17740.text: It shall be a shelter and shade from the heat of the day, a secret refuge from the downpour and from rain.

17741.text: ¶Let me sing for my Beloved/_a love song about his vineyard:/My Beloved had a vineyard/_on the fertile brow of a hill.

17742.text: /He cultivated it, clearing it of stones,/_and planted it with choice vines./He built a watchtower in its midst/_and hewed for it a winepress as well./Then he expected it to yield grapes,/_but it produced wild grapes.

17743.text: ¶Now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and you men of Judea,/_please judge between me and my vineyard!

17744.text: /What more could have been done/_for my vineyard than I have done for it?/When I expected it to yield grapes,/_why did it produce wild grapes?

17745.text: /Let me now inform you/_what I will do to my vineyard:/I will have its hedge removed/_and let it be burned;/I will have its wall broken through/_and let it be trampled.

17746.text: /I will make it a desolation:/_it shall neither be pruned nor hoed,/_but briars and thorns shall overgrow it./Moreover, I will forbid the rainclouds to rain on it.

17747.text: ¶The vineyard of Jehovah of Hosts is the house of Israel/_and the people of Judah his cherished grove./He expected justice,/_but there was injustice;/he expected righteousness,/_but there was an outcry.

17748.text: ¶Woe to those who join house to house/_and link field to field till no place is left,/and you are restricted to dwell/_in the centers of the land!

17749.text: /Jehovah of Hosts spoke this in my hearing:/_Surely many buildings shall lie desolate,/_large and fine houses unoccupied.

17750.text: /A ten‐acre vineyard shall yield but one bath,/_a homer of seed but an ephah.

17751.text: ¶Woe to those who go after liquor/_as soon as they arise in the morning,/who linger at night parties, inflamed by wine!

17752.text: /There are harps and lyres,/_drums, flutes, and wine at their banquets,/but they regard not what Jehovah does,/_nor perceive his hands at work.

17753.text: ¶Therefore are my people exiled/_without knowing why;/their best men die of famine,/_their masses perish with thirst.

17754.text: /Sheol becomes ravenous,/_opening its mouth insatiably;/into it descend their elite with the masses,/_their boisterous ones and revelers.

17755.text: ¶Mankind is brought low/_when men debase themselves,/_causing the eyes of the high‐minded to be downcast.

17756.text: /But Jehovah of Hosts will be exalted/_by a just judgment,/the holy God show himself holy/_by his righteousness.

17757.text: /Then shall his sheep feed in their pasture,/_and proselytes eat in the ruins of the affluent.

17758.text: ¶Woe to those drawn to sin by vain attachments,/_hitched to transgression like a trailer,

17759.text: /who think, Let him quickly speed up his work/_so we may see it!/Let the plan of the Holy One of Israel/_soon come to pass, and we will know!

17760.text: ¶Woe to those who suppose what is evil to be good/_and what is good, evil!/They put darkness for light/_and light for darkness;/they make bitterness sweet and the sweet bitter.

17761.text: ¶Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes/_and clever in their own view!

17762.text: ¶Woe to those who are valiant at drinking wine/_and champions at mixing liquor!

17763.text: ¶Woe to those who acquit the guilty for a bribe/_but deny justice to the innocent!

17764.text: /As a blazing fire consumes stubble,/_and as dry weeds wane before the flame,/so shall their roots decay away/_and their blossoms fly up like dust.¶For they have despised the law of Jehovah of Hosts/_and reviled the words of the Holy One of Israel.

17765.text: ¶Therefore the anger of Jehovah is kindled/_against his people:/he draws back his hand against them/_and strikes them;/the mountains quake, and their corpses/_lie like litter about the streets./Yet for all this his anger is not abated;/_his hand is upraised still.

17766.text: ¶He raises an ensign to distant nations/_and summons them from beyond the horizon./Forthwith they come, swiftly and speedily.

17767.text: /Not one of them grows weary,/_nor does any stumble;/_they do not drowse or fall asleep./Their waist‐belts come not loose/_nor their sandal thongs undone.

17768.text: /Their arrows are sharp;/_all their bows are strung./The tread of their warhorses resembles flint;/_their chariot wheels revolve like a whirlwind.

17769.text: /They have the roar of a lion;/_they are aroused like young lions:/growling, they seize the prey, and escape,/_and none comes to the rescue.

17770.text: ¶He shall be stirred up against them in that day,/_even as the Sea is stirred up./And should one look to the land,/_there too shall be a distressing gloom,/for the daylight shall be darkened/_by an overhanging mist.

17771.text: ¶In the year of King Uzziah’s death, I saw my Lord seated on a throne, highly exalted, the skirt of his robe filling the sanctuary.

17772.text: Seraphs stood by him overhead, each having six wings— with two they could veil their presence, with two conceal their location, and with two fly about.

17773.text: They called out to one another, and said,¶▼Most holy is Jehovah of Hosts;/_the consummation of all the earth is his glory!

17774.text: ¶The threshold shook to its foundation at the sound of those who called and a mist filled the temple.

17775.text: ¶Then I thought, Woe is me: I have been struck dumb, for I am a man of unclean speech, and I live among a people of unclean speech: I have seen the King, Jehovah of Hosts, with my own eyes!

17776.text: ¶Then one of the seraphs flew to me carrying an ember which he had taken with tongs from the altar.

17777.text: Touching it to my mouth, he said, See, this has touched your lips: your sins are taken away, your transgressions atoned for.

17778.text: ¶Then I heard the voice of my Lord saying, Whom shall I send? Who will go for us? And I replied, Here am I; send me!

17779.text: ¶And he said, Go, and say to these people,¶▼Go on hearing, but not understanding;/_Go on seeing, but not perceiving.

17780.text: /Make the heart of these people grow fat;/_dull their ears and shut their eyes,/lest they see with their eyes/_and hear with their ears,/understand in their heart,/_and repent, and be healed.

17781.text: ¶And I replied, For how long, my Lord? And he said,¶▼Until the cities lie desolate/_ and without inhabitant,/the houses without a man,/_ and the land ravaged to ruin.

17782.text: ¶For Jehovah will drive men away,/_and great shall be the exodus/_from the centers of the land.

17783.text: /And while yet a tenth of the people/_remain in it, or return,/_they shall be burned./But like the terebinth or the oak/_when it is felled, whose stump remains alive,/so shall the holy offspring be what is left standing.

17784.text: ¶When Ahaz son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, was king of Judah, Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel came up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but could not overpower it.

17785.text: ¶And when the house of David was informed that Aram was leading Ephraim on, the king’s mind and the minds of his people were shaken, as trees in a forest are shaken by a gale.

17786.text: ¶Then Jehovah said to Isaiah, Go out and meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear‐Jashub, at the end of the aqueduct of the Upper Reservoir, on the road to the Laundry Plaza.

17787.text: Say to him, See to it that you remain calm and unafraid. Be not intimidated by these two smoking tail ends of kindling, by the burning anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah,

17788.text: even though Aram has conceived an evil plot against you, as has Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, who say,

17789.text: Let us invade Judah and stir up trouble there. We will take it for ourselves by force and set a ruler over it—the son of Tabeal.

17790.text: ¶Thus says my Lord Jehovah:/_It shall not occur or transpire.

17791.text: /For as surely as Damascus is the capital of Aram/_and Rezin the head of Damascus,/within sixty‐five years shall Ephraim/_be shattered as a nation.

17792.text: /But as surely as Samaria is the capital of Ephraim/_and the son of Remaliah the head of Samaria,/you will not believe it,/_because you are not loyal.

17794.text: Ask a sign for yourself from Jehovah your God, whether in the depths below or in the heights above.

17795.text: But Ahaz said, I will not. I will not put Jehovah to the test.

17796.text: ¶Then Isaiah said, Take heed, O house of David! Is it not enough for you to try the patience of men? Must you also try the patience of my God?

17797.text: ¶Therefore will my Lord of himself give you a sign: the young woman with child shall give birth to a son and name him Immanuel.

17798.text: Cream and honey will he eat by the time he has learned to reject what is evil and choose what is good.

17799.text: But before the child learns to reject the evil and choose the good, the land whose two rulers you loathe shall lie forsaken.

17800.text: Jehovah will bring upon you and your people and your father’s house a day unlike any since Ephraim broke away from Judah—the day of the king of Assyria.

17801.text: ¶In that day Jehovah will signal for the flies from the far rivers of Egypt and for the bees in the land of Assyria.

17802.text: And they will come and settle with one accord in the river beds of the prairie and in rocky ravines, and by all ditches and water holes.

17803.text: In that day my Lord will use a razor hired at the River—the king of Assyria—to shave your head and the hair of your legs, and to cut off even your beard.

17804.text: ¶In that day a man will keep alive a young cow and a pair of sheep.

17805.text: And because of their plentiful milk, men will eat the cream. All who remain in the land will feed on cream and honey.

17806.text: ¶In that day every plot of ground with a thousand vines worth a thousand pieces of currency shall be briars and thorns.

17807.text: Men will go there with bows and arrows, for the whole land shall revert to wilderness.

17808.text: And on all hillsides cultivated by the hoe you will no longer go for fear of the briars and thorns, but they shall serve as a cattle range, a terrain for sheep to tread down.

17809.text: ¶Jehovah said to me, Take a large scroll and write on it in common script: Hasten the plunder, hurry the spoil.

17810.text: And I called in reliable witnesses, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah, to witness for me.

17811.text: ¶And when I had been with the prophetess, she conceived and gave birth to a son. And Jehovah said to me, Name him Maher‐Shalal‐Hash‐Baz.

17812.text: For before the child knows how to say, Father, or Mother, the wealth of Damascus and the plunder of Samaria will be brought before the king of Assyria.

17814.text: ¶Because these people have rejected/_the Waters of Shiloah, which flow gently,/_and rejoice in Rezin and the son of Remaliah,

17815.text: /therefore will my Lord/_cause to come up over them/the great and mighty waters of the River—/_the king of Assyria in all his glory./He will rise up over all his channels/_and overflow all his banks.

17816.text: /He will sweep into Judea like a flood/_and, passing through, reach the very neck;/his outspread wings will span/_the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.

17817.text: ¶Though nations form pacts,/_they shall be routed./Give heed, all you distant lands!¶You may take courage in one another,/_but shall be in fear;/you may arm yourselves,/_but shall be terrorized.

17818.text: /Though you hold consultations,/_they shall come to nought;/though you make proposals,/_they shall not prove firm: God is with us!

17819.text: ¶Jehovah spoke to me, clasping my hand, and admonished me not to follow the ways of these people. For he said,

17820.text: ¶Do not call a conspiracy all that these people/_call a conspiracy;/be not afraid or awed/_by the thing they fear.

17821.text: /But sanctify Jehovah of Hosts,/_making him your fear, him your awe.

17822.text: /And to you he will be a sanctuary,/_but to the two houses of Israel/a stumbling block or obstructing rock,/_and a snare, catching unawares/_the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

17823.text: /Many will stumble into them,/_and when they fall shall be broken,/and when they become ensnared/_shall be taken captive.

17824.text: ¶For Jehovah has said, Bind up the testimony;/_seal the law among my disciples.

17825.text: /I will wait for Jehovah,/_who hides his face from the house of Jacob,/and expect him.

17826.text: ¶As for me and the children Jehovah has given me, we shall be signs and portents in Israel from Jehovah of Hosts, who dwells in Mount Zion.

17827.text: ¶When men tell you to inquire of mediums and spiritists who huddle together and mutter, say to them, Should not a people inquire of their God? Should one inquire of the dead on behalf of the living

17828.text: for doctrine and for a testimony? Surely, while they utter such words devoid of light,

17829.text: they roam about embittered by hunger; and when they are hungry, they become enraged and, gazing upward, curse their king and their God.

17830.text: They will look to the land, but there shall be a depressing scene of anguish and gloom; and thus are they banished into outer darkness.

17831.text: ¶But it shall not be gloomy to those who have been in anguish for her. In the past he humbled the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali, but at the last he will exalt the Sea Route by the Jordan in Galilee of the nations.

17832.text: ¶The people walking in darkness/_have seen a bright light;/on the inhabitants of the land/_of the shadow of Death/_has the light dawned.

17833.text: /You have enlarged the nation/_and increased its joy;/they rejoice at your presence/_as men rejoice at harvest time,/_or as men are joyous when they divide spoil.

17834.text: ¶For you have smashed the yoke/_that burdened them,/the staff of submission,/_the rod of those who subjected them,/_as in the day of Midian’s defeat.

17835.text: /And all boots used in battle/_and tunics rolled in blood/_have become fuel for bonfires.

17836.text: ¶For to us a child is born, a son appointed,/_who will shoulder the burden of government./He will be called/_Wonderful Counsellor, One Mighty in Valor,/_a Father for Ever, a Prince of Peace—

17837.text: /that sovereignty may be extended/_and peace have no end;/that, on the throne of David/_and over his kingdom,/his rule may be established and upheld/_by justice and righteousness/_from this time forth and forever./The zeal of Jehovah of Hosts will accomplish it.

17838.text: ¶This message my Lord sent to Jacob,/_and it shall befall Israel.

17839.text: /And the entire people—/_Ephraim and those who dwell in Samaria—/shall know of it,/_who say in pride and arrogance of heart,

17840.text: /The bricks have fallen down,/_but we will rebuild with hewn stone;/the sycamores have been felled,/_but we will replace them with cedars!

17841.text: /But Jehovah will strengthen/_Rezin’s enemies against them/_when he stirs up their adversaries:

17842.text: /Aramaeans from the east/_and Philistines from the west/will devour Israel with open mouth.¶Yet for all this his anger is not abated;/_his hand is upraised still.

17843.text: ¶But the people do not turn back/_to him who smites them,/_nor will they inquire of Jehovah of Hosts.

17844.text: /Therefore Jehovah will cut off from Israel/_head and tail, palm top and reed, in a single day;

17845.text: /the elders or notables are the head,/_the prophets who teach falsehoods, the tail.

17846.text: /The leaders of these people have misled them,/_and those who are led are confused.

17847.text: /My Lord is not pleased with their young men,/_nor does he pity their fatherless and widows,/because all alike are godless malefactors,/_and every mouth utters profanities.¶Yet for all this his anger is not abated;/_his hand is upraised still.

17848.text: ¶Wickedness shall be set ablaze like a fire,/_and briars and thorns shall it consume;/it shall ignite the jungle forests,/_and they shall billow upward/_in mushrooming clouds of smoke.

17849.text: /At the wrath of Jehovah of Hosts/_the earth is scorched,/and people are but fuel for the fire./_Men will have no compassion for one another.

17850.text: /They will snatch on the right, yet remain hungry;/_they will devour on the left, but not be satisfied:/men will eat the flesh of their own offspring.

17851.text: /Manasseh will turn against Ephraim/_and Ephraim against Manasseh,/and both will combine against Judah.¶Yet for all this his anger is not abated;/_his hand is upraised still.

17852.text: ¶Woe to those who enact unjust laws,/_who draft oppressive legislation—

17853.text: /denying justice to the needy,/_depriving the poor of my people of their right,/making plunder of widows,/_mere spoil of the fatherless!

17854.text: ¶What will you do in the day of reckoning/_when the holocaust overtakes you from afar?/To whom will you flee for help?/_Where will you leave your wealth?

17855.text: /There shall nothing remain/_but to kneel among the captives/_or fall among the slain.¶Yet for all this his anger is not abated;/_his hand is upraised still.

17856.text: ¶Hail the Assyrian, the rod of my anger!/_He is a staff—my wrath in their hand.

17857.text: /I will commission him against a godless nation,/_appoint him over the people/_deserving of my vengeance,/to pillage for plunder, to spoliate for spoil,/_to tread underfoot like mud in the streets.

17858.text: ¶Nevertheless, it shall not seem so to him;/_this shall not be what he has in mind./His purpose shall be to annihilate/_and to exterminate nations not a few.

17859.text: ¶He will say, Are not my commanders kings,/_one and all?

17860.text: /Has not Calno fared like Carchemish?/_Is not Hamath as Arpad,/_Samaria no better than Damascus?

17861.text: /As I could do this to the pagan states,/_whose statues exceeded/_those of Jerusalem and Samaria,

17862.text: /shall I not do to Jerusalem and its images/_even as I did to Samaria and its idols?

17863.text: ¶But when my Lord has fully accomplished his work in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, he will punish the king of Assyria for his notorious boasting and infamous conceit,

17864.text: because he said,¶▼I have done it by my own ability/_ and shrewdness, for I am ingenious./I have done away with the borders of nations,/_ I have ravaged their reserves,/_ I have vastly reduced the inhabitants.

17865.text: /I have impounded the wealth of peoples like a nest,/_and I have gathered up the whole world/_as one gathers abandoned eggs;/not one flapped its wings,/_or opened its mouth to utter a peep.

17866.text: ¶Shall an axe exalt itself/_above the one who hews with it,/or a saw vaunt itself/_over him who handles it?/As though the rod wielded him who lifts it up!/_As though the staff held up the one/_who is not made of wood!

17867.text: ¶Therefore will the Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_send a consumption into his fertile lands,/and cause a fire to flare up like a burning hearth,/_to undermine his glory:

17868.text: /the Light of Israel will be the fire/_and their Holy One the flame,/and it shall burn up and devour/_his briars and thorns in a single day.

17869.text: /His choice forests and productive fields/_it will consume, both life and substance,/_turning them into a rotting morass.

17870.text: /And the trees left of his forest shall be so few,/_a child could record them.

17871.text: ¶In that day those who survive of Israel/_and who escape of the house of Jacob/will no longer rely on him who struck them,/_but will truly rely on Jehovah,/_the Holy One of Israel:

17872.text: /of Jacob a remnant will return/_to the One Mighty in Valor.

17873.text: ¶For though your people, O Israel,/_be as the sands of the sea,/_only a remnant will return;/although annihilation is decreed,/_it shall overflow with righteousness.

17874.text: /For the Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_will carry out the utter destruction/_decreed upon the whole earth.

17875.text: ¶Therefore, thus says my Lord,/_Jehovah of Hosts:/O my people who inhabit Zion,/_be not afraid of the Assyrians,/though they strike you with the rod/_or raise their staff over you,/_as did the Egyptians.

17876.text: /For my anger will very soon come to an end;/_my wrath will become their undoing.

17877.text: ¶Jehovah of Hosts will raise the whip against them,/_as when he struck the Midianites/_at the Rock of Oreb./His staff is over the Sea,/_and he will lift it over them/_as he did to the Egyptians.

17878.text: /In that day their burdens shall be lifted/_from your shoulders,/_their yoke removed from your neck:/the yoke that wore away your fatness/_shall by fatness wear away.

17879.text: ¶He advances on Aiath, passes through Migron;/_at Micmash he marshals his weaponry.

17880.text: /They cross over the pass,/_stopping overnight at Geba./Ramah is in a state of alarm,/_Gibeah of Saul is fleeing.

17881.text: /Cry out, O Daughter of Gallim!/_Hear her, Laishah; answer her, Anathoth!

17882.text: /Madmenah has moved out of the way,/_the inhabitants of Gebim are in full flight.

17883.text: /This same day he will but pause at Nob/_and signal the advance/against the mountain of the Daughter of Zion,/_the hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶Then will my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_shatter the towering trees with terrifying power;/the high in stature shall be hewn down,/_the lofty ones leveled.

17885.text: /The dense forests shall be battered down/_with the force of iron,/and Lebanon fall spectacularly.

17886.text: ¶A shoot will spring up from the stock of Jesse/and a branch from its graft bear fruit.

17887.text: ¶The Spirit of Jehovah will rest upon him—/_the spirit of wisdom and of understanding,/the spirit of counsel and of valor,/_the spirit of knowledge/_and of the fear of Jehovah.

17888.text: /His intuition will be guided/_by the fear of Jehovah;/he will not judge by what his eyes see,/_nor establish proof by what his ears hear.

17889.text: /He will judge the poor with righteousness,/_and with equity arbitrate for the lowly in the land;/he will smite the earth with the rod of his mouth/_and with the breath of his lips slay the wicked.

17890.text: /Righteousness will be as a band about his waist,/_faithfulness a girdle round his loins.

17891.text: ¶Then shall the wolf dwell among lambs/_and the leopard lie down with young goats;/calves and young lions will feed together,/_and a youngster will lead them to pasture.

17892.text: /When a cow and bear browse,/_their young will rest together;/_the lion will eat straw like the ox.

17893.text: /A suckling infant will play near the adder’s den,/_and the toddler reach his hand/_over the viper’s nest.

17894.text: /There shall be no harm or injury done/_throughout my holy mountain,/for the earth shall be filled/_with the knowledge of Jehovah/as the oceans are overspread with waters.

17895.text: ¶In that day the sprig of Jesse,/_who stands for an ensign to the peoples,/shall be sought by the nations,/_and his rest shall be glorious.

17896.text: /In that day my Lord will again raise his hand/_to reclaim the remnant of his people—/those who shall be left out of Assyria,/_Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath,/_and the islands of the sea.

17897.text: /He will raise the ensign to the nations/_and assemble the exiled of Israel;/he will gather the scattered of Judah/_from the four directions of the earth.

17898.text: ¶Ephraim’s jealousy shall pass away/_and the hostile ones of Judah be cut off;/Ephraim will not envy Judah,/_nor Judah resent Ephraim.

17899.text: /But they will swoop on the Philistine flank/_toward the west,/_and together plunder those to the east;/they will take Edom and Moab at hand’s reach,/_and the Ammonites will obey them.

17900.text: ¶Jehovah will dry up the tongue/_of the Egyptian Sea by his mighty wind;/he will extend his hand over the River/_and smite it into seven streams/_to provide a way on foot.

17901.text: /And there shall be a pathway out of Assyria/_for the remnant of his people who shall be left,/as there was for Israel/_when it came up from the land of Egypt.

17902.text: ¶In that day you will say,/_I praise you, O Jehovah./Although you have been angry with me,/_your anger is turned away/_and you have consoled me.

17903.text: /In the God of my salvation I will trust without fear;/_for Jehovah was my strength and my song/_when he became my salvation.

17904.text: /Then shall you rejoice in drawing water/_from the fountains of salvation.

17905.text: ¶In that day you will say,/_Give thanks to Jehovah; invoke his name./Make known his deeds among the nations;/_commemorate his exalted name.

17906.text: /Sing in praise of Jehovah,/_who has performed wonders;/_let it be acknowledged throughout the earth!

17907.text: /Shout and sing for joy, O inhabitants of Zion,/_for renowned among you is the Holy One of Israel.

17908.text: ¶An oracle concerning Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw in vision:

17909.text: ¶Raise the ensign on a barren mountain;/_sound the voice among them!/Beckon them with the hand to advance/_into the precincts of the elite.

17910.text: /I have charged my holy ones,/_called out my valiant ones:/my anger is not upon those who take pride in me.

17911.text: ¶Hark! A tumult on the mountains,/_as of a vast multitude./Hark! An uproar among kingdoms,/_as of nations assembling:/Jehovah of Hosts is marshaling an army for war.

17912.text: /They come from a distant land beyond the horizon—/_Jehovah and the instruments of his wrath—/to cause destruction throughout the earth.

17913.text: ¶Lament, for the Day of Jehovah is near;/_it shall come as a violent blow from the Almighty.

17914.text: /Then shall every hand grow weak/_and the hearts of all men melt.

17915.text: /They shall be terrified, in throes of agony,/_seized with trembling like a woman in labor./Men will look at one another aghast,/_their faces set aflame.

17916.text: ¶The Day of Jehovah shall come/_as a cruel outburst of anger and wrath/to make the earth a desolation,/_that sinners may be annihilated from it.

17917.text: /The stars and constellations of the heavens/_will not shine./When the sun rises, it shall be obscured;/_nor will the moon give its light.

17918.text: ¶I have decreed calamity for the world,/_punishment for the wicked;/I will put an end to the arrogance of insolent men/_and humble the pride of tyrants.

17919.text: /I will make mankind scarcer than fine gold,/_men more rare than gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /I will cause disturbance in the heavens/_when the earth is jolted out of place/by the anger of Jehovah of Hosts/_in the day of his blazing wrath.

17921.text: ¶Then, like a deer that is chased,/_or a flock of sheep that no one rounds up,/each will return to his own people/_and everyone flee to his homeland.

17922.text: /Whoever is found shall be thrust through;/_all who are caught shall fall by the sword.

17923.text: /Their infants shall be dashed in pieces before their eyes,/_their homes plundered, their wives ravished.

17924.text: /See, I stir up against them the Medes,/_who do not value silver, nor covet gold.

17925.text: /Their bows shall tear apart the young./_They will show no mercy to the newborn;/their eye will not look with compassion on children.

17926.text: ¶And Babylon, the most splendid of kingdoms,/_the glory and pride of Chaldeans, shall be thrown down/as God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.

17927.text: ¶Never shall it be reinhabited;/_it shall not be resettled through all generations./Nomads will not pitch their tents there,/_nor will shepherds rest their flocks in it.

17928.text: /But wild animals will infest it,/_and its buildings overflow with weasels;/birds of prey will find lodging there/_and demonic creatures prance about in it.

17929.text: /Jackals will cry out from its palaces,/_howling creatures from its amusement halls./Her time draws near;/_Babylon’s days shall not be prolonged.

17930.text: ¶Jehovah will have compassion on Jacob/_and once again choose Israel;/he will settle them in their own land,/_and proselytes will adhere to them/_and join the house of Jacob.

17931.text: /The nations will take them/_and bring them to their own place./And the house of Israel will possess them/_as menservants and maidservants/_in the land of Jehovah:/they will take captive their captors/_and rule over their oppressors.

17932.text: ¶In the day Jehovah gives you relief from grief and anguish and from the arduous servitude imposed on you,

17933.text: you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon, and say,¶▼How the tyrant has met his end/_ and tyranny ceased!

17934.text: /Jehovah has broken the staff of the wicked,/_ the rod of those who ruled—

17935.text: /him who with unerring blows/_struck down the nations in anger,/who subdued peoples in his wrath/_by relentless oppression.

17936.text: /Now the whole earth is at rest and at peace;/_there is jubilant celebration!

17937.text: /The pine trees, too, rejoice over you,/_as do the cedars of Lebanon:/Since you have been laid low,/_no hewer has risen against us!

17938.text: ¶Sheol below was in commotion because of you,/_anticipating your arrival;/on your account it roused all the spirits/_of the world’s leaders,/causing all who had ruled nations/_to rise up from their thrones.

17939.text: /All alike were moved to say to you,/_Even you have become powerless as we are!/You have become like us!

17940.text: ¶Your glory has been cast down to Sheol,/_along with the music of your lyres./Beneath you is a bed of maggots;/_you are covered with worms.

17941.text: /How you have fallen from the heavens,/_O morning star, son of the dawn!/You who commanded the nations/_have been hewn down to earth!

17942.text: ¶You said in your heart, I will rise in the heavens/_and set up my throne above the stars of God;/I will seat myself/_in the mount of assembly of the gods,/_in the utmost heights or Zaphon.

17943.text: /I will ascend above the altitude of the clouds;/_I will make myself like the Most High!

17944.text: ¶But you have been brought down to Sheol,/_to the utmost depths of the Pit.

17945.text: /Those who catch sight of you/_stare at you, wondering,/Is this the man who made the earth shake/_and kingdoms quake,

17946.text: /who turned the world into a wilderness,/_demolishing its cities,/permitting not his captives to return home?

17947.text: ¶All rulers of nations lie in state,/_each among his own kindred.

17948.text: /But you are cast away unburied/_like a repugnant fetus,/exposed like the slain disfigured by the sword,/_whose mangled remains are thrown in a gravel pit.

17949.text: ¶You shall not share burial with them,/_for you have destroyed your land/_and murdered your people./May the brood of miscreants/_never more be mentioned!

17950.text: /Prepare for the massacre of their sons,/_in consequence of their fathers’ deeds,/lest they rise up again/_and take possession of the world,/and fill the face of the earth with cities.

17951.text: ¶I will rise up against them, says Jehovah of Hosts./_I will cut off Babylon’s name and remnant,/_its offspring and descendants, says Jehovah.

17952.text: /I will turn it into swamplands, a haunt for ravens;/_I will sweep it with the broom of destruction,/says Jehovah of Hosts.

17953.text: ¶Jehovah of Hosts made an oath, saying,¶As I foresaw it, so shall it happen;/_as I planned it, so shall it be:

17954.text: ¶I will break Assyria in my own land,/_trample them underfoot on my mountains;/their yoke shall be taken from them,/_their burden removed from their shoulders.

17955.text: /These are things determined upon the whole earth;/_this is the hand upraised over all nations.

17956.text: /For what Jehovah of Hosts has determined,/_who shall revoke?/When his hand is upraised, who can turn it away?

17957.text: ¶In the year King Ahaz died, came this oracle:

17958.text: ¶Rejoice not, all you Philistines,/_now that the rod which struck you is broken./From among the descendants of that snake/_shall spring up a viper,/and his offspring shall be a fiery flying serpent.

17959.text: /The elect poor shall have pasture,/_and the needy recline in safety./But your descendants I will kill with famine,/_and your survivors shall be slain.

17960.text: ¶Wail at the gates; howl in the city!/_Utterly melt away, you Philistines!/From the North shall come pillars of smoke,/_and no place he has designated shall evade it.

17961.text: /What shall then be told the envoys of the nation?/_Jehovah has founded Zion;/let his longsuffering people find refuge there.

17962.text: ¶An oracle concerning Moab:¶When in one night Ar is devastated,/_Moab shall be silenced;/when in one night Kir is razed,/_Moab shall be destroyed.

17963.text: ¶They will go up to the sanctuaries,/_and in Dibon to the hill shrines, to weep;/they will wail in Moab over Nebo and Medeba./_Every head shall be bald, every beard cut off.

17964.text: /They will wear sackcloth openly;/_on the housetops and in the streets/they will altogether wail and give way to weeping.

17965.text: ¶Heshbon will cry for help, as will Elealeh;/_their appeal shall be heard as far as Jahaz./They will sound the alarm/_to summon the armed men of Moab,/but their spirit shall be broken.

17966.text: /My heart will cry out for Moab;/_its fugitives will reach Zoar/_and as far as Eglath Shelishiah./In tears they will ascend the slopes of Luhith;/_on the road to Horonaim/they will raise the cry of catastrophe.

17967.text: ¶For the Waters of Nimrim shall be desolate;/_the grass shall dry up, vegetation disappear,/_and no green foliage shall remain.

17968.text: /The surplus they have acquired,/_and their personal belongings,/they will carry away/_over the Valley of the Willows.

17969.text: /The cry of calamity/_shall encompass the land of Moab;/the sound of it shall reach Eglaim/_and echo as far as Beer Elim.

17970.text: ¶Although the Waters of Dibon shall flow with blood,/_yet will I impose more than this upon Dibon:/I will bring lions upon the fugitives of Moab/_and on those who remain in the land.

17971.text: ¶Send couriers to those who rule in the earth,/_from Sela in the desert/_to the mountain of the Daughter of Zion.

17972.text: /Like fluttering birds forced out of the nest,/_so are Moab’s women at the fords of Arnon.

17973.text: /Provide a solution, they say; judge our case!/_Overshadow us at high noon as though it were night!/Shelter those dispossessed;/_betray not the refugees!

17974.text: /Let the exiles of Moab dwell with you;/_be a refuge to them from the aggressors!¶When oppressors are no more/_and violence has ceased,/_when tyrants are destroyed from the earth,

17975.text: ¶then, in loving kindness,/_shall a throne be set up in the abode of David,/and in faithfulness a judge sit on it/_who will maintain justice and expedite righteousness.

17976.text: ¶We have heard of the glories of Moab,/_of its excessive pride and its boasting,/_of its outbursts of false propaganda.

17977.text: /For this shall the Moabites be made to lament,/_and all have cause to bewail Moab:/they shall groan at the ruin of Kir Hareseth/_in utter dejection.

17978.text: ¶For the vineyards of Heshbon shall wither;/_the ruling nations will smite Sibmah’s vines./Its runner vines reached Jazer,/_trailing through the desert;/_its branches spread abroad across the sea.

17979.text: /Therefore I will mourn as Jazer mourns/_for the vines of Sibmah;/I will water you with my tears,/_O Heshbon and Elealeh,/when your shouts of cheer/_over the summer fruit and harvest are stilled.

17980.text: /The joyful festivity will be gone from the orchards;/_no shouts of delight shall sound in the vineyards./The wine treaders will tread no wine in the presses;/_the vintage shout I will bring to an end.

17981.text: ¶My breast will vibrate like a harp for Moab,/_my inmost being for Kir Hareseth.

17982.text: /For when the Moabites weary themselves/_with petitioning on the hill shrines,/and enter their sanctuaries to pray,/_it shall be to no avail.

17983.text: ¶These things Jehovah spoke hitherto about Moab.

17984.text: But now Jehovah has said, Within three years, as the term of a lease, Moab’s glory shall become ignominy. For all its large populace there shall be very few left, and those of no account.

17985.text: ¶An oracle concerning Damascus:¶Damascus shall cease to be a city/_and become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: /The cities of Aroer shall lie forsaken/_and become places for herds to recline,/_where no one will disturb them.

17987.text: /When Ephraim’s defense comes to an end,/_so shall the sovereignty of Damascus:/as with the glory of the children of Israel,/_so shall it be with Aram’s remnant,/says Jehovah of Hosts.

17988.text: ¶In that day Jacob’s glory shall wane,/_and his fatness of body become leanness.

17989.text: /After being like a harvest of ripe grain,/_whose ears are reaped by the armful,/he will become like ears plucked/_in the Valley of Rephaim

17990.text: /when only the gleanings are left,¶or when an olive tree is beaten,/_having two or three berries in the topmost bough,/or four or five in its most fruitful branch,/_says Jehovah, the God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶In that day men will have regard to their Maker,/_and their eyes look to the Holy One of Israel,

17992.text: /and regard not the altars,/_the works of their hands,/nor look to things their fingers have made—/_the idols of prosperity and the shining images.

17993.text: ¶In that day their mighty cities shall be like the deserted towns of the Hivites and Amorites, which they abandoned before the Israelites during the desolation.

17994.text: ¶For you have forgotten your God, your salvation,/_and not remembered the Rock, your fortress./Therefore, though you plant choice crops/_and sow hybrid seed,

17995.text: /and though you make them thrive/_the day you plant them,/causing them to sprout/_the very morning you sow them,/yet shall the harvest vanish/_in a day of diseases and incurable pain.

17996.text: ¶Woe to the many peoples in an uproar,/_who rage like the raging of the seas—/tumultuous nations, in commotion/_like the turbulence of mighty waters!

17997.text: /Nations may roar like the roaring of great waters,/_but when he rebukes them they will flee far away;/they will be driven before the wind/_like chaff on the mountains,/_or as whirling dust in a storm.

17998.text: /At evening time shall be the catastrophe,/_and before morning they shall be no more./This is the lot of those who plunder us,/_the fate of those who despoil us.

17999.text: ¶Woe to the land of buzzing wings/_beyond the rivers of Cush,

18000.text: /which sends emissaries by sea,/_in swift craft across the water!/They say, Go speedily, you messengers!¶Go to a people perpetually on the move,/_a nation dreaded far and wide,/a people continually infringing,/_whose rivers have annexed their lands.

18001.text: ¶All you who live in the world,/_you inhabitants of the earth,/look to the ensign/_when it is lifted up in the mountains;/heed the trumpet when sounded!

18002.text: ¶For thus said Jehovah to me:/_I will watch in silence over my dwelling place/when the searing heat overtakes the reapers,/_and when the rainclouds appear/_amid the fever of reaping.

18003.text: /For before the harvest,/_when the time of flowering is past/and the set blossoms are developing into young fruit,/_they will cut down the fruit‐bearing twigs with knives/_and remove the new branches by slashing.

18004.text: /All shall be left to the birds of prey/_of the mountains/_and to the beasts of the land:/the birds of prey will feed on them all summer/_and the beasts of the land all winter.

18005.text: ¶At that time shall tribute be brought/_to Jehovah of Hosts/from a nation perpetually on the move,/_from a nation dreaded far and wide,/a people continually infringing,/_whose rivers have annexed their lands,/to the place of the name of Jehovah of Hosts:/_Mount Zion.

18006.text: ¶An oracle concerning Egypt:¶When Jehovah enters Egypt riding on swift clouds,/_the idols of Egypt will rock at his presence/_and the Egyptians’ hearts melt within them.

18007.text: ¶I will stir up the Egyptians against the Egyptians;/_they will fight brother against brother/and neighbor against neighbor,/_city against city and state against state.

18008.text: /Egypt’s spirit shall be drained from within;/_I will frustrate their plans,/and they will resort to the idols and to spiritists,/_to mediums and witchcraft.

18009.text: ¶Then will I deliver the Egyptians/_into the hand of a cruel master;/a harsh ruler will subject them,/_says the Lord, Jehovah of Hosts.

18010.text: ¶The waters of the lakes shall ebb away/_as stream beds become desolate and dry.

18011.text: /The rivers shall turn foul,/_and Egypt’s waterways recede and dry up./Reeds and rushes shall wither;

18012.text: vegetation adjoining canals and estuaries,/_ and all things sown along irrigation channels,/shall shrivel and blow away and be no more.

18013.text: /Fishermen will deplore their lot/_and anglers in canals bemoan themselves;/those who cast nets on water/_will be in misery.

18014.text: /Manufacturers of combed linen/_and weavers of fine fabrics will be dismayed.

18015.text: /The textile workers will know despair,/_and all who work for wages suffer distress.

18016.text: ¶The ministers of Zoan are utter fools;/_the wisest of Pharaoh’s advisers give absurd counsel./How can you say to Pharaoh,/_We ourselves are as wise as the first rulers?

18017.text: /Where are your wise men indeed?/_Let them please tell you, if they can discern it,/what Jehovah of Hosts has in mind for Egypt!

18018.text: ¶The ministers of Zoan have been foolish,/_the officials of Noph deluded;/_the heads of state have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /Jehovah has permeated them/_with a spirit of confusion;/they have misled Egypt in all that it does,/_causing it to stagger like a drunkard into his vomit.

18020.text: /And there shall be nothing the Egyptians/_can do about it,/neither head nor tail, palm top or reed.

18021.text: ¶In that day the Egyptians will be as women, fearful and afraid at the brandishing hand Jehovah of Hosts wields over them.

18022.text: The land of Judah shall become a source of terror to the Egyptians; all reminded of it shall dread what Jehovah of Hosts has in store for them.

18023.text: ¶In that day five Hebrew‐speaking cities in the land of Egypt will swear loyalty to Jehovah of Hosts. One shall be known as the City of Righteousness.

18024.text: ¶In that day there shall be an altar erected to Jehovah in the midst of the land of Egypt and a monument to Jehovah at its border.

18025.text: They shall serve as a sign and testimony of Jehovah of Hosts in the land of Egypt: when they cry out to Jehovah because of the oppressors, he will send them a savior, who will take up their cause and deliver them.

18026.text: ¶Jehovah will make himself known to the Egyptians, and the Egyptians shall know Jehovah in that day. They will worship by sacrifice and offerings, and make vows to Jehovah and fulfill them.

18027.text: Jehovah will smite Egypt, and by smiting heal it: they will turn back to Jehovah, and he will respond to their pleas and heal them.

18028.text: ¶In that day there shall be a highway from Egypt to Assyria. Assyrians shall come to Egypt and Egyptians go to Assyria, and the Egyptians shall labor with the Assyrians.

18029.text: ¶In that day Israel shall be the third party to Egypt and to Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth.

18030.text: Jehovah of Hosts will bless them, saying, Blessed be Egypt my people, Assyria the work of my hands, and Israel my inheritance.

18031.text: ¶In the year the general who was sent by Sargon king of Assyria came to Ashdod and took it by combat,

18032.text: Jehovah had spoken through Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, Go and ungird the sackcloth from your loins and remove the shoes from your feet. And he had done so, going naked and barefoot.

18033.text: ¶Then Jehovah said, Just as my servant Isaiah has gone naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and portent against Egypt and Cush,

18034.text: so shall the king of Assyria lead away the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, both young and old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks uncovered—to Egypt’s shame.

18035.text: Men shall be appalled and perplexed at Cush, their hope, and at Egypt, their boast.

18036.text: ¶In that day shall the inhabitants of this isle say, See what has become of those we looked up to, on whom we relied for help and deliverance from the king of Assyria! How shall we ourselves escape?

18037.text: ¶An oracle concerning the Wilderness of the West:¶Like tornadoes sweeping through the South,/_they come from the steppes, a land of terror.

18038.text: ¶A grim vision has been revealed to me:/_the traitor in the act of treachery,/_the destroyer laying waste./Attack, O Elamites! Lay siege, you Medes!/_All the sighing that Babylon has caused/_I will bring to an end.

18039.text: ¶Therefore my whole frame is racked with trembling;/_throes of agony have seized me like a woman in labor./I am tormented beyond giving heed;/_I am too distraught to see.

18040.text: /My mind reels, I am paralyzed with fear;/_the nightfall I longed for has become a horror to me:

18041.text: /They prepare tables;/_they deck them with candlesticks./They are eating and drinking .../_Mobilize, you commanders! Oil the armor!

18042.text: ¶Because of this my Lord said to me,/_Go and appoint a watchman/_who will report what he sees.

18043.text: /Let him watch for chariots with teams of horses,/_riders on asses and riders on camels./He must be most vigilant, fully alert.

18044.text: /Then the lookout cried,/_I have been standing on the watchtower/day in and day out, my Lord;/_night after night I have stood guard.

18045.text: /Now they come: cavalry and teams of horses!/_And he gave the reply,/She has fallen; Babylon has fallen./_All her idol gods he has razed to the ground.

18046.text: ¶To you who know me, who are of my fold,¶I have reported what I heard/_from Jehovah of Hosts, the God of Israel.

18047.text: ¶An oracle concerning Dumah:¶Men call to me from Seir,/_Watchman, what remains of the night?/_Watchman, how much of the night is left?

18048.text: ¶The watchman replies,/_Morning comes, though it is still night./If you would ascertain it,/_do so by repenting and coming back.

18049.text: ¶An oracle concerning those in Arabia:¶You wandering bands of Dedanites,/_who sojourn in the forests of Arabia,

18050.text: ¶bring water to greet the thirsty;/_meet the fugitives with food,/O inhabitants of the land of Tema.

18051.text: /For they flee from destruction,/_from the bared sword, the drawn bow/_and the severity of war.

18052.text: ¶On account of this, my Lord said to me, Within a year, as the term of a lease, Kedar’s glory shall fully expire.

18053.text: And the number of valiant archers remaining of the sons of Kedar shall be few. Jehovah, the God of Israel, has spoken it.

18054.text: ¶An oracle concerning the Arena of Spectacles:¶Whatever is the matter with you,/_causing you all at once/_to climb onto the housetops?

18055.text: ¶You resounded with loud cheers—/_a tumultuous town, a city of revelry!/But your slain were not killed by the sword;/_they did not die in battle!

18056.text: /Your chiefs, altogether in flight,/_are captured without using the bow;/all of you left behind are caught easily/_before you can get away.

18057.text: ¶Because of this I said,¶Turn your attention from me,/_though I weep bitterly;/hasten not to comfort me/_at the ruin of the Daughter of my People.

18058.text: ¶For my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts, has in store¶a day of commotion and trampling and riot/_in the Arena of Spectacles,/a day of battering down walls,/_and of crying in distress, To the mountains!

18059.text: ¶When Elam takes up the quiver,/_and horses are harnessed to the chariots of Aram,/_and Kir uncovers the armor,

18060.text: /then shall your choice valleys fill with chariots,/_and cavalry take up positions at your gateways.

18061.text: /And in the day Judea’s defensive screen is removed,/_you will look to the forest home as protection.

18062.text: ¶When you saw the city of David increasingly breached,/_you conserved water in the Lower Reservoir.

18063.text: /You took a census of the buildings in Jerusalem,/_tearing down buildings to fortify your wall.

18064.text: /You built cisterns between the walls/_for the water from the Old Reservoir,/but you did not look to its Maker,/_nor have regard for the One who designed it long ago.

18065.text: ¶In such a day my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/_calls for weeping and lamentation,/_for austerity and wearing sackcloth.

18066.text: /Instead, there is mirth and merrymaking,/_the killing of cattle and slaughter of sheep,/eating meat and drinking wine:/_Let us dine and drink, for tomorrow we die!

18067.text: ¶Jehovah of Hosts revealed this to my ears: Such wickedness cannot be forgiven you till you die, says my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts.

18068.text: ¶Thus said my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts:/_Go and see that steward, Shebna,/_overseer of the palace.

18069.text: /Say to him, What are you up to?/_Who do you think you are,/that you have hewn yourself a tomb here,/_like those who hew their sepulchres up high,/carving out graves for themselves in the rock?

18070.text: ¶Jehovah will hurl you away/_as an athlete hurls a missile;/he will make you soar like a dart.

18071.text: /He will bind you tightly about/_and send you spinning like a top/_into an open country./There shall you die,/_and your inglorious conveyance there/_shall be a disgrace to your master’s house.

18072.text: /I will thrust you out of office;/_you will be expelled from your post.

18073.text: ¶In that day I will commission my servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah:

18074.text: I will clothe him with your robe and bind your girdle on him; I will appoint him your jurisdiction. And he will be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.

18075.text: I will invest him with the keys of the house of David: when he opens none shall shut, when he shuts none shall open.

18076.text: I will fasten him as a nail in a sure place, and he will be a throne of glory to the house of his father.

18077.text: Upon him shall be hung all the glory of his father’s house: his descendants and posterity, including all the lesser vessels, from ordinary bowls to the most common containers.

18078.text: ¶In that day, says Jehovah of Hosts, the nail that was fastened in a sure place shall be removed. It shall be dislodged and fall, and the burden hanging on it cut off. Jehovah has spoken it.

18079.text: ¶An oracle concerning Tyre:¶Sound your sirens, O merchant ships!/_For Tyre is laid waste,/_stripped of warehouse and wharf./On their way from the land of Kittim/_shall they be informed of it.

18080.text: ¶Be dumbfounded, you inhabitants of the isles,/_who were amply replenished/_by the traders of Sidon crossing the seas.

18081.text: /The grain of Shihor, the harvest of the Nile,/_was her source of revenue upon the high seas/when she became the merchant of nations.

18082.text: ¶Be dismayed, O Sidon, because the Sea,/_the mighty haven of the Sea, has declared,/I no longer labor and bear children!/_I no longer rear young men or raise virgins!

18083.text: /When the news of Tyre reaches Egypt,/_men will be in anguish at the report.

18084.text: ¶Move on to Tarshish lamenting,/_you inhabitants of the isles.

18085.text: /Is this your festive city of ancient origin,/_whose feet led her to settle far‐off lands?

18086.text: /Who devised this stratagem against Tyre,/_the imperial city,/whose traders were princes,/_whose merchants the world’s celebrities?

18087.text: /Jehovah of Hosts devised it,/_to make all glorying in excellence a profanity,/and the world’s celebrities an utter execration.

18088.text: ¶Overflow your land like the Nile,/_O Daughter of Tarshish: the harbor is no more.

18089.text: /Jehovah will stretch out his hand over the Sea/_and distress kingdoms;/he will give orders concerning the merchant city/_that her ports of haven be destroyed.

18090.text: /He will say, You will frolic no more,/_O ravished virgin, Daughter of Sidon./Get up and cross over to Kittim,/_though even there you will find no rest.

18091.text: ¶So too with the land of the Chaldeans,/_the people who founded Tyre for shipping./Was it not the Assyrians who set up observatories,/_exposed its fortifications, and caused her downfall?

18092.text: /Sound your sirens, O merchant ships;/_your haven is desolate!

18093.text: ¶In that day Tyre shall be forgotten seventy years, the lifetime of a king. And at the end of seventy years, Tyre shall be as the harlot in the song:

18094.text: ¶Take a lyre and go about the town,/_O forgotten harlot./Play skillfully; sing song after song,/_that you may be remembered.

18095.text: ¶For after seventy years, Jehovah will revisit Tyre. And she will return to her trade and hire herself out to all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth.

18096.text: Her merchandise and hire shall be consecrated to Jehovah; it shall not be hoarded or stored up. Her commerce shall provide for those who dwell in the presence of Jehovah, that they may eat their fill and be elegantly clothed.

18097.text: ¶Lo! Jehovah will lay waste the earth and empty it;/_he will disfigure its surface/_and scatter its inhabitants.

18098.text: /And it shall be with priest as with people,/_with master as with servant,/with mistress as with maid,/_with seller as with buyer,/with borrower as with lender,/_with debtor as with creditor—

18099.text: /when the earth is sacked,/_it shall be utterly ravaged./Jehovah has given word concerning it.

18100.text: ¶The earth shall pine away,/_the world miserably perish;/_the elite of the earth shall be made wretched.

18101.text: /The earth lies polluted under its inhabitants:/_they have transgressed the laws,/changed the ordinances,/_set at nought the ancient covenant.

18102.text: /The curse devours the earth,/_for those who dwell on it have incurred guilt;/because of it the population of the earth/_shall be diminished/and little of mankind remain.

18103.text: ¶The new wine withers on languishing vines,/_making all the lighthearted lament.

18104.text: /The rhythm of drums ceases,/_the revelers’ din stops;/_the pulsating of lyres comes to an end.

18105.text: /Men no longer drink wine amid song;/_liquor has turned bitter to drinkers.

18106.text: /The towns of disorder are broken up;/_all houses are shuttered, that none may enter.

18107.text: /Outside is heard the clamor for wine,/_though all joy has become gloom:/_the earth’s vitality is gone.

18108.text: /Havoc remains in the city;/_the gates lie battered to ruin.

18109.text: ¶Then shall it happen in the earth among the nations/_as when an olive tree is beaten,/_or as grapes are gleaned when the vintage is ended.

18110.text: /Then will these lift up their voice and shout for joy,/_and those from across the sea/_exult at Jehovah’s ingenuity.

18111.text: /Because of it they will give glory to Jehovah/_in the regions of sunrise,/and in the isles of the sea/_to the name of Jehovah, the God of Israel.

18112.text: ¶From a sector of the earth we hear singing:/_Glorious are the righteous!/Whereas I thought, I am wasting away;/_I am weakening:/woe is me; the traitors have been treacherous,/_the turncoats have deceitfully betrayed!

18113.text: ¶Terrors and pitfalls and traps await you,/_O inhabitants of the earth:

18114.text: /those who flee at the sound of terror/_shall fall into a pit,/and those who get up from the pit/_shall be caught in a trap./For when the windows on high are opened,/_the earth shall shake to its foundations.

18115.text: ¶The earth shall be crushed and rent;/_the earth shall break up and cave in;/_the earth shall convulse and lurch.

18116.text: /The earth shall reel to and fro like a drunkard,/_sway back and forth like a shanty;/its transgressions weigh it down,/_and when it collapses it shall rise no more.

18117.text: ¶In that day will Jehovah deal on high/_with the hosts on high/_and on earth with the rulers of the earth.

18118.text: /They shall be herded together/_like prisoners to a dungeon/and shut in confinement many days, as punishment.

18119.text: /The moon will blush and the sun be put to shame,/_when Jehovah of Hosts manifests his reign/_in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,/and his glory in the presence of his elders.

18120.text: ¶In that day you will say,/_O Jehovah, you are my God;/I will extol you by praising your name./_For with perfect faithfulness/you have performed wonders,/_things planned of old.

18121.text: /You have made the city a heap of rubble,/_fortified towns a ruin—/heathen mansions shall no more form cities,/_nor ever be rebuilt!

18122.text: /For this will powerful peoples revere you,/_a community of tyrannous nations fear you.

18123.text: ¶You were a refuge for the poor,/_a shelter for the needy in distress,/a covert from the downpour/_and shade from the heat./When the blasts of tyrants beat down/_like torrents against a wall,

18124.text: /or like scorching heat in the desert,¶you quelled the onslaughts of the heathen:/_as burning heat by the shade of a cloud,/you subdued the power of tyrants.

18125.text: ¶In this mountain will Jehovah of Hosts prepare/_a sumptuous feast for all peoples,/a feast of leavened cakes, succulent and delectable,/_of matured wines well refined.

18126.text: /In this mountain he will destroy/_the veil that veils all peoples,/the shroud that shrouds all nations,

18127.text: by abolishing Death forever./My Lord Jehovah will wipe away/_the tears from all faces;/he will remove the reproach of his people/_from throughout the earth./Jehovah has spoken it.

18128.text: ¶In that day you will say, This is our God,/_whom we expected would save us./This is Jehovah for whom we have waited;/_let us joyfully celebrate his salvation!

18129.text: ¶For in this mountain rests the hand of Jehovah,/_and under him Moab shall be trampled down/_as straw is trampled in a dung pit.

18130.text: /For when he stretches his hands/_into the midst of it,/as a swimmer spreads his hands to swim,/_he will pull down his pride in the attempt.

18131.text: /Your highly walled fortifications/_he will lay low by razing them to the ground,/even with the dust.

18132.text: ¶In that day shall this song be sung in the land of Judah:¶Our city is strong; salvation he has set up/_as walls and barricades!

18133.text: ¶Open the gates to let in the nation/_righteous because it keeps faith.

18134.text: /Those whose minds are steadfast, O Jehovah,/_you preserve in perfect peace,/for in you they are secure.

18135.text: ¶Ever trust in Jehovah,/_for Jehovah, Yah, is an everlasting Rock.

18136.text: /He has put down the elite inhabitants/_of the exalted city/by casting it to the ground,/_laying it even with the dust.

18137.text: /It is trodden underfoot by the feet of the poor,/_by the footsteps of those impoverished.

18138.text: ¶The path of the righteous is straight;/_you pave an undeviating course for the upright.

18139.text: /In the very passage of your ordinances/_we anticipate you, O Jehovah;/_the soul’s desire is to contemplate your name.

18140.text: /My soul yearns for you in the night;/_at daybreak my spirit within me seeks after you./For when your ordinances are on the earth,/_the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.

18141.text: ¶Though favor be shown the wicked,/_they will not learn righteousness;/in a land of uprightness they remain perverse/_and see not the glory of Jehovah.

18142.text: /O Jehovah, your hand is lifted up,/_but they perceive it not./Let them perceive with dismay/_your zeal for your people/when the fire prepared for your enemies/_consumes them.

18143.text: ¶O Jehovah, you bring about our peace;/_even all that we have accomplished/_you have done for us.

18144.text: /O Jehovah, our God, lords other than you/_have ruled over us,/_but you alone we recall by name.

18145.text: /They are dead, to live no more,/_spirits who will not rise up;/you appoint them to destruction,/_wiping out all recollection of them.

18146.text: /You have enlarged the nation, O Jehovah,/_and by enlarging it gained glory for yourself;/you have withdrawn all borders in the earth.

18147.text: ¶O Jehovah, in their distress they remembered you;/_they poured out silent prayers/_when your chastisements were upon them.

18148.text: /As a woman about to give birth/_cries out from her pangs during labor,/so were we at your presence, O Jehovah.

18149.text: /We were with child; we have been in labor,/_but have brought forth only wind./We have not wrought salvation in the earth,/_that the inhabitants of the world might not fall.

18150.text: ¶Yet shall your dead live when their bodies arise./_You will say to them,/Awake, and sing for joy,/_you who abide in the dust:/your dew is the dew of sunrise!/_For the earth shall cast up its dead.

18151.text: ¶Come, O my people, enter your chambers/_and shut the doors behind you;/hide yourselves a little while/_until the wrath is past.

18152.text: /For now will Jehovah come out of his dwelling place/_to punish the inhabitants of the earth/_for their iniquities;/the earth will uncover the blood shed upon it/_and no more conceal its slain.

18153.text: ¶In that day will Jehovah,/_with his great and powerful sword,/punish severely Leviathan,/_the evasive maritime serpent,/Leviathan, that devious sea monster,/_when he slays the dragons of the Sea.

18154.text: ¶In that day, sing of the earth/_as of a delightful vineyard

18155.text: of which I, Jehovah, am keeper./I water it constantly, watch over it night and day,/_lest anything be amiss.

18156.text: /I have no more anger toward her./_Should briars and thorns come up,/I will ruthlessly attack them/_and altogether set them ablaze.

18157.text: /But should they take hold of me for a refuge/_and make peace with me,/_they shall be reconciled to me.

18158.text: /For in days to come, when Jacob takes root/_and Israel bursts into blossom,/the face of the earth shall fill with fruit.

18159.text: ¶Was he smitten as were his smiters?/_Or was he slain as were they who slew him?

18160.text: /You have dealt with them/_by utterly banishing them, O Jehovah./By his fierce blasts they were flung away/_in the day of the burning east wind.

18161.text: ¶But by this shall Jacob’s iniquity be expiated,/_as a result of this his sins removed:/when he makes like crushed chalkstone/_all altar stones,/leaving no idols of prosperity/_and shining images standing.

18162.text: /Because of them the fortified cities lie forlorn,/_deserted habitations, forsaken like a wilderness;/steers forage and recline there,/_stripping bare the young branches of trees.

18163.text: /A harvest of twigs dries, broken off by women/_who come to light their fires with them./They are not a discerning people.Therefore their Maker shows them no mercy;/_he who formed them favors them not.

18164.text: ¶In that day Jehovah will thresh out his harvest from the torrent of the River to the streams of Egypt. But you shall be gleaned one by one, O children of Israel.

18165.text: ¶In that day a loud trumpet shall sound, and they who were lost in the land of Assyria and they who were outcasts in the land of Egypt shall come and bow down to Jehovah in the holy mountain at Jerusalem.

18166.text: ¶Woe to the garlands of glory/_of the drunkards of Ephraim!/Their crowning splendor has become as fading wreaths/_on the heads of the opulent overcome with wine.

18167.text: ¶My Lord has in store one mighty and strong:/_as a ravaging hailstorm sweeping down,/or like an inundating deluge of mighty waters,/_he will hurl them to the ground by his hand.

18168.text: /The proud garlands of the drunkards of Ephraim/_shall be trodden underfoot.

18169.text: /And the fading wreaths, the crowns of glory/_on the heads of the opulent,/shall be like the first‐ripe fruit/_before summer harvest:/he who sees it devours it/_the moment he has hold of it.

18170.text: ¶In that day shall Jehovah of Hosts/_be as a crown of beauty and wreath of glory/_to the remnant of his people:

18171.text: /a spirit of justice to him who sits in judgment,/_a source of strength/to those who repulse the attack at the gates.

18172.text: ¶These too have indulged in wine/_and are giddy with strong drink:/priests and prophets have gone astray through liquor./_They are intoxicated with wine/and stagger because of strong drink;/_they err as seers, they blunder in their decisions.

18173.text: /For all tables are filled with vomit;/_no spot is without excrement.

18174.text: ¶Whom shall he give instruction?/_Whom shall he enlighten with revelation?/Weanlings weaned from milk,/_those just taken from the breast?

18175.text: /For it is but line upon line, line upon line,/_precept upon precept, precept upon precept;/a trifle here, a trifle there.

18176.text: ¶Therefore, by incomprehensible speech/_and a strange tongue/_must he speak to these people,

18177.text: /to whom he said, This is rest; let the weary rest!/_This is a respite! But they would not listen.

18178.text: /So to them the word of Jehovah remained:/_Line upon line, line upon line,/precept upon precept, precept upon precept;/_a trifle here, a trifle there, that,/persisting, they might lapse into stumbling/_and break themselves,/become ensnared and be taken captive.

18179.text: ¶Therefore hear the word of Jehovah, you scoffers/_who preside over these people in Jerusalem.

18180.text: /You have supposed, by taking refuge in deception/_and hiding behind falsehoods,/to have covenanted with Death,/_or reached an understanding with Sheol, that,/should a flooding scourge sweep through the earth,/_it shall not reach you.

18181.text: ¶Therefore, thus says my Lord Jehovah:/_I lay in Zion a stone, a keystone,/a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation./_They who believe it will not do rashly.

18182.text: ¶I will make justice the measure,/_righteousness the weight;/a hail shall sweep away your false refuge/_and waters flood the hiding place.

18183.text: /Your covenant with Death shall prove void,/_your understanding with Sheol have no effect:/when the flooding scourge sweeps through,/_you shall be overrun by it.

18184.text: /As often as it sweeps through,/_you shall be seized by it:/morning after morning it shall sweep through,/_by day and by night it shall seize you;/it shall cause terror merely to hear word of it.

18185.text: /Then shall come to pass the proverb:/_The couch is too short to stretch out on,/_the covering too narrow to wrap oneself in.

18186.text: ¶For Jehovah will rise up/_as he did on Mount Perazim,/and be stirred to anger, as in the Valley of Gibeon—/_to perform his act, his unwonted act,/_and do his work, his bizarre work.

18187.text: /Now therefore scoff not,/_lest your bonds grow severe,/for I have heard utter destruction/_decreed by my Lord, Jehovah of Hosts,/upon the whole earth.

18188.text: ¶Give heed, and hear my voice!/_Be attentive, and listen to what I say!

18189.text: /Will the plowman be forever plowing to sow seed,/_disking and harrowing the same ground?

18190.text: /When he has smoothed its surface,/_does he not sprinkle fennel and scatter cumin?/Does he not demarcate wheat from barley/_and plant buckwheat in its own plot?

18191.text: /His God instructs him,/_directing him in the proper procedure.

18192.text: ¶Fennel is not threshed with a sharp‐toothed sledge,/_nor is a cartwheel rolled over cumin:/fennel is beaten out with a stick/_and cumin with a rod.

18193.text: /Domestic grain is ground;/_one does not go on endlessly threshing it./It cannot be ground/_by driving horse and threshing cart over it.

18194.text: /These things originate with Jehovah of Hosts,/_whose counsel is wonderful,/_whose inspiration is surpassing.

18195.text: ¶Woe to Ariel—/_Ariel, the city where David lodged!/Though you add year to year,/_and the feastdays recur in succession,

18196.text: /yet will I distress Ariel:/_there shall be mourning and sorrow/_when she becomes as my altar hearth.

18197.text: /I will encamp against you round about,/_and beleaguer you with assault posts,/_and erect siege installations against you.

18198.text: /And when you have been laid low,/_you will speak from the ground,/_your words uttering out of the dust:/your voice from the ground/_shall be like that of a medium;/your sayings shall whisper out of the dust.
